concept.title: Cheque protocol
concept.shortdesc: Cheque protocol solves a common multi-sig use-cases

conbody.p: There are many scenarios multi-sig can be used to achieve efficiency and privacy.
Cheque protocol is an in-development multi-sig protocol with privacy protection and extensibility. TokenScript will support it natively smart contract's support will be enabled through a new ERC.

note.p: We take an MVP-first, paper-later appraoch. The paper will be based on the protocol for send ether by identifier attestation MVP.

section.title: Multi-sig is efficient

ol.li: A CEO authories an employee to withdraw up to 500USD per day from an account.

section.p: Observe that only the 2nd transaction causes money to change hand, yet the first is a blockchain transaction, consuming gas nontheless. The process can be turned into a multi-sig process where the CEO sends the authorisation off chain to the employee, who use it, and some information (100USD), sign again to with draw the money.

Such multi-sig protocols can be built individially, but a protocol makes it easier to support this kind of feature through wallets, dapp websites and the eco-system. This is what Cheque protocol is for.

section.title: Cheque protocol adds privacy protection
section.p: Furthermore, proper cryptographic hiding is needed to protect privacy involving protocols that ues attestations.

ol.li: Alice sends a signed cheque to Bob. Not knowing his choice of Ethereum address, Alice hides his email address in a Pedersen Commitment.
Bob obtains an 3rd party attestation that he owns the email address.
Using the Cheque, and the email address attestation, Bob redeems the 1 Eth promised.

section.p: In such a case, implementers should not be left to roll out their own crypto, but rather take an existing library to protect Bob's email address from being learned by any observer. Cheque protocol included the necessary crypto - in this case Pedersen Commitment and Zero Knowledge Proof - so that blockchain Token developers can implement their version of such protocol in their business scenario.
This use-case is our MVP implementation of Cheque protocol. The cheque protocol paper will be published based on this MVP result.

section.title: Cheque protocol can improve security
section.p: Smart use of Cheque protocol can improve security through minimising counter-party risk and attack surface.

For example, an exchange can get an order from a user to sell their cryptocurrency at certain price. Later when the order can be filled, the exchange can counter-sign the order and execute it. This can happen even when the user is offline.

Therefore the user does not need to deposite their cryptocurrency into the exchange's account prior to the trade, minimising counter party risk. The exchange account will be holding cryptocurrency only for a short time, minimising attack surface.
